comments:
In many modern systems, mechanical elements are tightly coupled with electronic
components and embedded computers. Mechatronics is the study of how these domains
are interconnected, and this hands-on, project-based course provides an integrated
introduction to the fundamental components within each of the three domains, including:
mechanical elements (prototyping, materials, actuators and sensors, transmissions, and
fundamental kinematics), electronics (basic circuits, filters, op amps, discrete logic, and
interfacing with mechanical elements), and computing (interfacing with the analog world,
microprocessor technology, basic control theory, and programming).
Students generally found this course "tough, but it's probably one of the most
rewarding classes at Penn" because they "felt that they could come in knowing very little
and gain a workable understanding of complex subject material." Many others
emphasized that they had "learned a lot hands-on and practical skills." One student
commented that "the course provides an ideal setting for integrating concepts from all the
various courses one might have taken and applying those theories."
Students found Professor Fiene a good professor and one student commented that
"Professor Fiene's ability to come up with such fun and interesting projects is
astounding." Students felt that learned a lot of useful and practical information from
Professor Fiene's class.
Most students felt that the course "requires a large time investment, but the effort
is appropriate for the depth and importance of the material and the educational value of
the course." Students recommended this class to anyone interested in Robotics and
Mechatronics, but to be aware that the course "requires a lot of time." Some prerequisites
for this class exist; students must be in Junior or Senior standing in MEAM and have
some programming background.
